comments:
This final clinical nursing course focuses on the integration and synthesis of scientific knowledge with clinical nursing practice and the development of the professional nursing role. Building on content from prior courses, students will develop an understanding of management of patient care from the perspective of the individual client and family to groups of clients and eventually to management of health care systems. Principles of leadership, accountability and change will be integrated throughout. The process of transition from the student role to that of the professional nurse will be facilitated through discussion of organizational systems, professional issues, mechanisms for evaluation of care and the role of the nurse as patient advocate and change agent. Clinical seminar content will build on core content and will provide an exposure to advanced nursing concepts within the area of specialty practice. Application of conceptual models to clinical practice will be discussed and nursing research will be integrated throughout the course.

As a whole, students thought the course content was fairly applicable to their future nursing careers. The seminar portion of the class was highly regarded by the students since it provided them an opportunity to practice for the NCLEX and discuss relevant case studies. A large number of students, however, commented that the lecture portion was “obsolete”, “dry”, and “unorganized.” One student summed up the feelings of the others by suggesting that the course “needs some serious revision.”

Students felt Professor Sochalski shared great stories about her nursing experience in a variety of areas and was described as “excellent”, “crazy enthusiastic”, and supportive. A few students commented that Professor Sochalski tended to read off of the slides. Though, in general, the students enjoyed Professor Sochalski’s personality and availability.

Overall, the students found the discussions and readings to be fair. The assignments, on the other hand, were viewed as “busy work” and “redundant.” Nonetheless, the class is required of all nursing students prior to graduation. Students somewhat recommend this course to majors but do not recommend it for non-Nursing majors. The pre-requisites for the course include NURS 321, 322, 340, 341 and co-requisite NURS 371.

This final clinical nursing course focuses on the integration and synthesis of scientific knowledge with clinical nursing practice and the development of the professional nursing role. Building on content from prior courses, students will develop an understanding of management of patient care from the perspective of the individual client and family to groups of clients and eventually to management of health care systems. A large number of students, however, commented that the lecture portion was “obsolete”, “dry”, and “unorganized.” One student summed up the feelings of the others by suggesting that the course “needs some serious revision.”

Student had only positive comments about Professor Rogers. One student stated that she “learned the most when [Professor Rogers] was lecturing.” Similarly, others found Professor Rogers “wonderful”, “helpful”, and able to help students when they needed it.

In general, the students found the discussions and readings to be fair. The assignments, on the other hand, were viewed as “busy work” and “redundant.” Nonetheless, the class is required of all nursing students prior to graduation. Students somewhat recommend this course to majors but do not recommend it for non-Nursing majors. The pre-requisites for the course include NURS 321, 322, 340, 341 and co-requisite NURS 371.

This final clinical nursing course focuses on the integration and synthesis of scientific knowledge with clinical nursing practice and the development of the professional nursing role. Building on content from prior courses, students will develop an understanding of management of patient care from the perspective of the individual client and family to groups of clients and eventually to management of health care systems. As a whole, students thought the course content was fairly applicable to their future nursing careers. A large number of students, however, commented that the lecture portion was “obsolete”, “dry”, and “unorganized.” One student summed up the feelings of the others by suggesting that the course “needs some serious revision.”

Students described Professor Polsky as “willing to discuss difficult topics.” Also, students praised Professor Polsky’s as “amazing”, supportive and readily available.

In general, the students found the discussions and readings to be fair. The assignments, on the other hand, were viewed as “busy work” and “redundant.” Nonetheless, the class is required of all nursing students prior to graduation. Students somewhat recommend this course to majors but do not recommend it for non-Nursing majors. The pre-requisites for the course include NURS 321, 322, 340, 341 and co-requisite NURS 371.
